div.l: Aleyn answerde Iohn wilt þou soo
Than will I be beneth be my crowne
And se howe gates þe mylle falles a down̄
In til þe troȝh þat schall be my desporte
Qduod Iohn in faith I may bene of ȝour͗e sorte
I am als euell a myller as arne ȝee
This myller͗e smyled of her͗e nycite
And thought alle þis nys done but for a wyle
Thei wene þat no man̄ may þam begile
But be my thryfte ȝit schall I bler͗e her͗e eye
For all þe sleight in her͗e philosophie
The mor͗e wil I stele crekes þat þei make
The mor͗e will I stele whan̄ I take
In stede of flour͗e þan will I ȝif hem branne
The grettest clerkes bene noȝht þe wisest men
As whilom to þe wolfe þus spake þe mar͗e
Of all her͗e arte counte I not a tar͗e
Oute of þe dor͗e he goith full priuely
Whan̄ þat he sawgh his tyme softely
He loketh up and down̄ til he hath founde
The clerkes horse þ̉er as he stode y bounde
Be hynde þe Mylle vndir a leuesell
And to þe hors he goith hym fair͗e and well
He strepeth of þe bridell riȝht onon̄
And whan̄ þe hors was louse he gynneth to gone
To warde þe fenne þer wild mares renne
And forth with wehe thurgh thykke and thynne
This Meller͗e goith a gayn̄ no worde he saide
But doith his note and with his clerkes pleyede
Till þat þer corne was fair͗e and wele y grounde
And when̄ þe mele was sakked and y bounde
This Iohn goith oute and fyndeth his hors a waye
And gan̄ to crie harrowe and wele awaye
Our͗e horse is loste Aleyn̄ be goddes bones
Step on þi fete come on man al at ones
Allas our͗e wardeyn hath his palfrey lorne
This Aleyn al forgate both mele and corne
All was oute of his mynde his husbondrye
What whilke weye is he gone he gan̄ to crie
The wyff come lepynge inwarde at a renne
She seith allas ȝour͗e horse goith to þe fenne
With wilde mares as faste as he may goo
Vnthank come on his honde þat bonde hym so
And he þat bett̉er schuld haf knytte þe reyne
Allas alleyn̄ qduod Iohn for cristes peyne
Leye doun̄ þi swerde and I will myn also
